text:
Hiii! If you’ve got a handful of good customers, my best advice is to do actual customer research Oftentimes marketing doesn’t do this directly but I’ve found it to help guide my growth marketing and content marketing strategies. 

Here’s a guide on that customer research process: <https://www.advanceb2b.com/blog/customer-research-guide-b2b-saas|https://www.advanceb2b.com/blog/customer-research-guide-b2b-saas>

attachments.title: Forget buyer personas – Here's your step-by-step guide to better customer research in B2B SaaS
attachments.text: Want to learn more about your ideal customers and identify business growth opportunities? Forget buyer personas – This is your complete guide to better customer research in B2B SaaS!
attachments.fallback: Forget buyer personas – Here's your step-by-step guide to better customer research in B2B SaaS

text: Any agency marketers using *headless WordPress* with your clients? I'd love know what you find are the biggest advantages compared to a) other CMS and b) normal WordPress

elements.text: Any agency marketers using
headless WordPress
with your clients? I'd love know what you find are the biggest advantages compared to a) other CMS and b) normal WordPress

text: Headless WordPress means that you are still using WordPress as your CMS but the front-end is separated from it. In other words, you have total freedom when it comes to designing it, you don't rely on some WordPress limitations. The biggest advantage is SEO and speed/performance. The weaknesses? Creating new pages (like landing pages) may be tricky and may require developer's help

elements.text: Headless WordPress means that you are still using WordPress as your CMS but the front-end is separated from it. In other words, you have total freedom when it comes to designing it, you don't rely on some WordPress limitations. The biggest advantage is SEO and speed/performance. The weaknesses? Creating new pages (like landing pages) may be tricky and may require developer's help

elements.text: Thanks
. From what I understand the GA Academy is a good place to start but it’s not targeted to content marketing pros specifically. Seeking a CM-angled GA course.

text: Most GA courses you find are going to be focused on ecommerce. The one <@UJJFDTN8G> linked is what I used to build a foundation 7-8 years ago as a content marketer.

elements.text: Most GA courses you find are going to be focused on ecommerce. The one
linked is what I used to build a foundation 7-8 years ago as a content marketer.

text: I didn't learn anything about ecommerce when I did it. It's a good platform for _anyone_ I'd say.

elements.text: I didn't learn anything about ecommerce when I did it. It's a good platform for
anyone
I'd say.

text:
I’m in the second lesson right now and all the examples they’re using are for ecommerce use cases (i.e., they’re illustrating the difference between metrics and dimensions using sales data from an ecommerce store). While this is helpful to understanding concepts, it’s not relevant to what I need to do and the data I need to parse as a content marketing strategist.
I’m not disagreeing with you in that it’s a good place to start for the basic understanding of how GA works, but I’m looking for a course specifically on “How to use GA for content marketing use cases”.

text:
Hey all! Question for any SaaS content marketers out there: Has anyone tried adding a "Listen to this blog post as audio" option at the top of their blog posts? If so, I'm curious to know:
• What impact did it have on engagement?
• What tool did you use to host/play the audio?
• How did you handle production—hire a freelancer, find a team member with a smooth radio voice? 
Thanks!

elements.text: Hey all! Question for any SaaS content marketers out there: Has anyone tried adding a "Listen to this blog post as audio" option at the top of their blog posts? If so, I'm curious to know:
What impact did it have on engagement?
What tool did you use to host/play the audio?
How did you handle production—hire a freelancer, find a team member with a smooth radio voice?
Thanks!

text: What are you hoping to measure?

elements.text: What are you hoping to measure?

text: As a content strategist for an agency, I have multiple data sets I need to measure depending on my clients’ goals, including traffic, referrals, engagement, assisted conversions, and organic channels. I have a basic understanding of how to generate reports for most of these. But I also know there’s room for a deeper mastery of my skills. So I was interested to see what was out there to guide content marketers specifically on leveling up their GA knowledge. Looks like there isn’t much out there (which also is an opportunity for an enterprising content marketing leader!)

text: I took a boot camp-style course from Jeff Sauer (Jeffalytics) a few years back. It was pretty helpful covered everything from basics to more advanced topics

elements.text: I took a boot camp-style course from Jeff Sauer (Jeffalytics) a few years back. It was pretty helpful covered everything from basics to more advanced topics

text:
<@ULDMZNHF0> CXL does have some good GA courses (intermediate and advanced). that said, i still don't know if any course will get you where you want to go.

in my experience, most good analytics learnings came from needing an answer to a really specific question vs. walking through a UI with someone who's explaining the vocabulary and ways to filter results.

i might also encourage you to get familiar with the Google Analytics Add-on for Google Sheets. it makes it much easier to build reports with the data you want in the format you want (versus the limitations of the GA UI).

once you're in Sheets (and/or Data Studio), it's also a lot easier to bring in other data sources.

elements.text:
CXL does have some good GA courses (intermediate and advanced). that said, i still don't know if any course will get you where you want to go.

in my experience, most good analytics learnings came from needing an answer to a really specific question vs. walking through a UI with someone who's explaining the vocabulary and ways to filter results.

i might also encourage you to get familiar with the Google Analytics Add-on for Google Sheets. it makes it much easier to build reports with the data you want in the format you want (versus the limitations of the GA UI).

once you're in Sheets (and/or Data Studio), it's also a lot easier to bring in other data sources.
